title: Multimillion-dollar mobile homes: Inside the tiny luxury houses on wheels that are gaining in popularity
text:
Good things really do come in small packages, especially when you have a big budget.

One family of eight recently dropped close to $2 million on a pimped-out tiny home on wheels, but they’re not the only ones paying top dollar for a compact home away from home according to Warwick Boswerger, co-owner of SLRV Expedition Vehicles.

Mr Boswerger is in the business of self-sufficient off-road vehicles and he says more Aussies than ever are embracing life on the road, but for this new generation of nomads. the idea of roughing it is out of the question.

“My clients now really want all the comforts they are used to at home in their vehicles, so the end product with our trucks is like having a nice modern unit,” he says.

Once upon a time a toilet meant five-star luxury in a caravan or camper, however today’s designer mobile homes aren’t even standard without Wi-Fi, full indoor and outdoor kitchens and zoned airconditioning.

The multimillion-dollar van he just completed for his cashed-up client was the most expensive vehicle Mr Boswerger has built to date, with the total cost he puts somewhere between $1.5 million and $2 million.

As well as a full internal kitchen, there is a MasterChef-worthy outdoor kitchen with the works, a washing machine, ducted heating and airconditioning throughout, sound systems and multiple televisions.

Upstairs there are six beds for the kids, and downstairs there is a main bedroom suite for the parents complete, with a full ensuite, then there is a huge lounge to seat up to 10 people.

The vehicle even has a spare electric lift-up bed for two more guests.

Although Mr Boswerger couldn’t reveal who had ordered the mega motor, the most extravagant he’s built to date, he says the orders are becoming increasingly elaborate as people expect their creature comforts to travel with them.

“Most of our clients are retirees, but not necessarily really wealthy people.

“They’re a lot of people who might be using their super, or people who’ve sold their house and decide they want to travel the world in one of these vehicles.

“They’ve worked hard all their life and they’re going to go out there and experience it.”

About 2.6 million domestic travellers aged between 55 and 70 took a caravan/motor home trip in 2018, according to data from Tourism Research Australia.

These numbers were up 12 per cent on the previous year and up a whopping 90 per cent since the early 2000s.

“There is quite a wide variety of people. We do also have some younger couples with kids who want to travel with their family,” he explains.

For less than the cost of an inner city apartment in most cities, or cheaper than a family home in many regional areas, homeowners with the urge to own portable property can set themselves up in an expedition vehicle.

“You’ve got three tiers, there are trucks that would be around the $350,000 mark, then your medium trucks would be around the $650,000 price and then obviously you’ve got your custom-built one that can go up to that couple of million dollar mark,” he says.

And Mr Boswerger says the investment these buyers make is in the knowledge that they never have to check into a hotel, sit on a train or book into an AirBnb.

“Plenty of people take these overseas. You can roll on and roll off a boat; lock up the whole thing, because all your valuables are safe and protected. Just hand your truck over at the wharf and then you just fly over to wherever and meet your truck on the next continent and off you go.”

“Or you could even spend months, if not years just travelling around Australia. If you’ve got a vehicle like one of these it allows you to comfortably go and see the whole country.

“The beauty of having one of these trucks is that you don’t have to pack up, or set up. When you get to a beautiful spot you just pull up, open the door, pull your chairs out and you’re done,” he says.
description: Aussies are choosing mobile homes with the lot so they can live on the road forever, and this one family is taking it to the next level, spending a whopping $2 million on their luxury van.
